content: i cord edge to avoid holes or gaps in the knitting when changing colours the two different colour yarns are twisted around each other on every row see image right which shows an example of two yarns being twisted around each other before the purl row is continued in the pink yarn working with 3 strands of yarn this first appears on day 4 and is used in several of the following motifs using 3 colours is a nordic/latvian knitting technique but not complicated if you follow these simple steps 1 hold 3 strands in your in your left hand 2 right side row as you pick up the colour to be used next move the strand over the top of the other strands and so on with each colour change although this twists the strands leading from the balls together they will be untwisted on the following row 3 wrong side row you move the strand to be used under the other strands and so on with each colour change basically untwisting the strands that became twisted on the previous rs round basically rs = over ws = under blocking - to block your scarf pin it out on a foam board i use children play mats if you have lace blocking wires these will easily thread through the i cord edge making the task quick and easy once pinned mist with warm water the warm water relaxes the fibres so they can be stretched into place and will hold these new positions once dry blocking helps correct any irregularities in stitch gauge and will improve definition and neatness of your patterns around the colour change areas care of naturally dyed yarns - your finished item should be gently hand washed in warm water using a mild detergent i like ecover or no rinse wool products such as eucalan before being laid flat to dry i would not recommend harsh machine washing for natural dyes even if the yarn used is labelled as superwash all of our natural colours have been dyed in small batches using age-old techniques with natural products many of which i have foraged locally from flower vegetable and tree matter only one animal dye is used by us cochineal pink which comes from south american insects but i have included it in the range because of the vibrancy of the colours that can be achieved with it all colours have been mordanted ie fixed with mineral extracts to ensure the maximum light and wash fastness available from each extract despite this naturally dyes fibres may fade darken or change slightly over the course of their lifetime this is part of the character some would say part of the charm of organic matter products and these fractional changes over a long period of time copyright 2024 suzi ashworth for folkestone harbour yarn should not discourage you from using environmentally friendly yarns you may also find that some excess colour particles come loose during the first few
